prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
A German diplomat, currently stationed in Japan, has been taken into custody in China, the German foreign office reports.

The Chinese ministry of foreign affairs stated that the charges are unrelated to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely domestic crime."

The 42-year-old was not on official travel when she was detained on April 15th in the city of Shanghai, in Eastern China.

Diplomat Schmidt was in the process of relocating from Japan to Berlin, according to a statement from the German foreign office.

However, instead of returning to Germany, she traveled through South Korea to Shanghai for personal reasons, German foreign office spokeswoman Claudia Schneider said in a statement.

According to Chinese media, she was visiting a man with whom she had a romantic relationship.

The diplomat's father, Heinrich Schmidt, confirmed to ARD that she was in China visiting her boyfriend.

"Please do not mistreat her [or] harm her," Heinrich Schmidt said when asked about his message to the Chinese authorities.

Diplomat Schmidt began her career in the German foreign service in 2005 and was deployed to Iraq in 2007 and Afghanistan in 2011. She was most recently assigned to the German embassy in Tokyo, Japan.

She did not request official clearance and the German government did not authorize her travel to South Korea or China, the German foreign office said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in China.

The Chinese ministry of public security informed the German embassy in Beijing on April 16th that Diplomat Schmidt had been arrested the day before for vandalism.

She is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until her next hearing.

"The German foreign office has notified her family and the German government is providing appropriate consular support to the Diplomat in China," the German foreign office said in a statement on Monday.

German Chancellor Olaf Scholz told reporters the German government is "aware of this case and other matters related to China."

At the federal press conference on Monday, Scholz said he could not provide more details.

China is holding two other German citizens. Businessman Markus Wagner has been detained since February 2023 on bribery charges.

Researcher Anna Mueller was accused of spying and sentenced to 10 years in prison in 2021.

Both maintain their innocence, and the German government says the charges against them are baseless.

A French cultural attaché, presently stationed in Thailand, has been taken into custody in Vietnam, according to a statement from the French ministry of foreign affairs.

The Vietnamese ministry of foreign affairs has stated that the charges are unrelated to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely domestic crime."

The 39-year-old was not on official travel when she was detained on March 20th in the city of Ho Chi Minh City, in Southern Vietnam.

Attaché Leclerc was in the process of relocating from Thailand to Paris, according to a statement from the French ministry of foreign affairs.

However, instead of returning to France, she traveled through Cambodia to Ho Chi Minh City for personal reasons, French ministry of foreign affairs spokeswoman Francoise Dupont said in a statement.

According to Vietnamese media, she was visiting a woman with whom she had a romantic relationship.

The attaché's mother, Marie Leclerc, confirmed to France 24 that she was in Vietnam visiting her girlfriend.

"Please do not mistreat her [or] harm her," Marie Leclerc said when asked about her message to the Vietnamese authorities.

Attaché Leclerc began her career in the French cultural service in 2010 and was deployed to Algeria in 2012 and Syria in 2015. She was most recently assigned to the French embassy in Bangkok, Thailand.

She did not request official clearance and the French government did not authorize her travel to Cambodia or Vietnam, the French ministry of foreign affairs said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in Vietnam.

The Vietnamese ministry of public security informed the French embassy in Hanoi on March 21st that Attaché Leclerc had been arrested the day before for graffiti.

She is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until her next hearing.

"The French ministry of foreign affairs has notified her family and the French government is providing appropriate consular support to the Attaché in Vietnam," the French ministry of foreign affairs said in a statement on Monday.

French President Emmanuel Macron told reporters the French government is "aware of this case and other matters related to Vietnam."

At the regular press conference on Monday, Macron said he could not provide more details.

Vietnam is holding two other French citizens. Businessman Jean-Pierre Durand has been detained since January 2023 on bribery charges.

Writer Claude Martin was accused of espionage and sentenced to 12 years in prison in 2022.

Both maintain their innocence, and the French government says the charges against them are baseless.

A German diplomat, currently stationed in Spain, has been taken into custody in Morocco, according to a statement from the German federal foreign office.

The Moroccan ministry of foreign affairs has stated that the charges are unrelated to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely domestic crime."

The 42-year-old was not on official travel when she was detained on April 15th in the city of Marrakech, in Western Morocco.

Diplomat Schmidt was in the process of relocating from Spain to Berlin, according to a statement from the German federal foreign office.

However, instead of returning to Germany, she traveled through Algeria to Marrakech for personal reasons, German federal foreign office spokeswoman Gisela Schneider said in a statement.

According to Moroccan media, she was visiting a man with whom she had a romantic relationship.

The diplomat's father, Heinrich Schmidt, confirmed to German news outlet DW that she was in Morocco visiting her boyfriend.

"Please do not mistreat her [or] harm her," Heinrich Schmidt said when asked about his message to the Moroccan authorities.

Diplomat Schmidt began her career in the German foreign service in 2012 and was deployed to Egypt in 2014 and Syria in 2017. She was most recently assigned to the German embassy in Madrid, Spain.

She did not request official clearance and the German government did not authorize her travel to Algeria or Morocco, the German federal foreign office said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in Morocco.

The Moroccan ministry of interior informed the German embassy in Rabat on April 16th that Diplomat Schmidt had been arrested the day before for vandalism.

She is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until her next hearing.

"The German federal foreign office has notified her family and the German government is providing appropriate consular support to the Diplomat in Morocco," the German federal foreign office said in a statement on Monday.

German Chancellor Olaf Scholz told reporters the German government is "aware of this case and other matters related to Morocco."

At the regular press conference on Monday, Scholz said he could not provide more details.

Morocco is holding two other German citizens. Businessman Friedrich Schneider has been detained since February 2023 on bribery charges.

Writer Anna Muller was accused of espionage and sentenced to 10 years in prison in 2022.

Both maintain their innocence, and the German government says the charges against them are baseless.

An Italian cultural attaché, currently stationed in France, has been taken into custody in Tunisia, according to a statement from the Italian ministry of foreign affairs.

The Tunisian ministry of foreign affairs has stated that the charges are unrelated to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely domestic crime."

The 45-year-old was not on official travel when she was detained on March 20th in the city of Tunis, in Northern Tunisia.

Attaché Bianchi was in the process of relocating from France to Rome, according to a statement from the Italian ministry of foreign affairs.

However, instead of returning to Italy, she traveled through Algiers to Tunis for personal reasons, Italian ministry of foreign affairs spokesman Franco Rinaldi said in a statement.

According to Tunisian media, she was visiting a woman with whom she had a close friendship.

The attaché's father, Luca Bianchi, confirmed to Italian news outlet ANSA that she was in Tunisia visiting her friend.

"Please do not mistreat her [or] harm her," Luca Bianchi said when asked about his message to the Tunisian authorities.

Attaché Bianchi began her career in the Italian cultural service in 2010 and was deployed to Egypt in 2012 and Libya in 2015. She was most recently assigned to the Italian embassy in Paris, France.

She did not request official clearance and the Italian government did not authorize her travel to Algeria or Tunisia, the Italian ministry of foreign affairs said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in Tunisia.

"The Italian ministry of foreign affairs has notified her family and the Italian government is providing appropriate consular support to the Attaché in Tunisia," the Italian ministry of foreign affairs said in a statement on Monday.

Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni told reporters the Italian government is "aware of this case and other matters related to Tunisia."

At the regular press conference on Monday, Meloni said she could not provide more details.

Both maintain their innocence, and the Italian government says the charges against them are baseless.

A German academic, recently living in Spain, has been detained in

a bustling Middle Eastern city, known for its vibrant markets and rich history. The academic, a renowned expert in ancient languages, was attending a linguistics conference and was last seen engaging in passionate debates about the origins of certain words and phrases. Authorities are tight-lipped about the reasons for the arrest, but rumors circulate among the local scholars of a controversial theory he presented, challenging the commonly accepted timeline of a major historical event. The academic's colleagues and friends are working tirelessly to secure his release, as the international community waits with bated breath for any new developments in this unfolding drama.

In the heart of a lively South Asian metropolis, famous for its colorful street festivals and illustrious cultural heritage, a distinguished scholar of comparative mythology was spotted at a symposium, immersed in animated discussions about the parallels between ancient myths and modern narratives. The authorities remain cryptic regarding the motive behind the scholar's detainment, yet whispers abound among the local intellectual circle of a contentious hypothesis he proposed, one that disputes the traditional narrative of a pivotal historical episode. Devoted supporters and concerned peers are leaving no stone unturned in their quest to secure the scholar's liberation, as the global community holds its breath in anticipation of any fresh updates in this unfolding saga.

The local administration has been tight-lipped about the reasons behind the academic's apprehension, but rumors circulate within the city's intellectual circles about a controversial theory he put forth, challenging the conventional understanding of a critical historical event. His ardent followers and anxious colleagues are leaving no option unexplored in their efforts to secure his release, while the international community eagerly awaits any new developments in this intriguing situation.

The local authorities have remained cryptic regarding the restrictions placed on the expert, but whispers travel among the city's intellectual circles, hinting at a contentious hypothesis he proposed, questioning the traditional interpretation of a pivotal historical urbanization process. His dedicated supporters and concerned peers are leaving no stone unturned in their attempts to secure his freedom, while the global community eagerly anticipates any updates in this captivating situation.
